results.notes:
These represent the same fruiting as seen in obs 333663. I visited the site and collected the fruit bodies. Tom Jasonis, who had originally found these, dehydrated a few of them and left most in-situ so that I could see them close up.

Habitat is spread gravel near a barbecue pit. The area in constructed so that the gravel readily drains whenever there’s rainfall (drain system submerged beneath the spread gravel). As seen in first two photos, stipes were buried more than halfway.

Apical pore at the end of a tubular beak.

Spores yellow in KOH, globose or nearly so, with lengths up to about 6.5 microns. Spores ornamented with fairly large triangular warts (~1 micron or maybe a bit larger). Spore walls thick.

As far as I can tell, species of Tulostoma mainly (if not virtually exclusively) occur in arid regions. The area where these were found has been anything but arid lately; lots of rainfall. However, perhaps the fact that the habitat is designed to drain readily mimics the quick wet-to-dry conditions that are apt to occur in a desert. Temperatures this past month or so have been well above average.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1157/2018_DSC3305

Habitat: old stands of Fagus sylvatica wood with scattered Picea abies, no Quercus sp. in the vicinity; steep mountain slope, southeast aspect; calcareous ground; shallow, skeletal, presumably locally somewhat acid soil (growing among Erica carnea), no clay present; half shade; dry and relatively warm place; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 5-7 deg C, elevation 885 m (2.900 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča; next to the trail from Soča 46 abandoned farm house to Planina Na skalah, just before the trail passes a sandy ravine, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Hemileccinum impolitum is a beautiful, all yellowish bolete, generally considered a rare find in Europe. However, this doesn’t seem to hold for Slovenia, since many records exist in Boletus Informaticus Data Base (Ref.7). The species is very similar to closely related Hemileccinum depilatum (Redeuilh) Šutara. The most important distinguishing traits are pilei surface and microscopic structure of pilei cutis. The latter species usually looks like having ‘hammered’ pileus. However, the only sure way to differentiate them is microscopic structure of their pilei cuticle. Hemileccinum depilatum has hymeniform-cellular cuticle with many club shaped to sub globose end cells. I found nothing like this in this find.

Growing solitary. Hut diameter 12 cm, stipe 12.5 cm long and almost 4 cm wide (max); hut somewhat sticky; no part of the fruitbody is bruising when cut or damaged; SP abundant, olive-beige, oac847.

results.notes:
A single small-sized sporocarp growing along the main park driveway in needle duff in mixed white pine and oak woods. The overall morphology can generally be inferred from the pictures.
The oval-shaped cap is 4.5 × 4.2 cm wide and 5 mm thick above the stipe. The gills are 4.5 mm wide max, rounded, sub-truncate to sub-attenuate to attenuate. The stipe is 5 cm long from the apex down to just above the bulb, 1 cm wide at the apex and just above the bulb and 7 mm wide at its narrowest point. The ring zone/annulus attachment point is situated 1.3 cm below the apex. The carrot-shaped bulb is 3.3 cm long and 2 cm wide max. The bulb was subterranean, but the stem above the bulb was entirely above the ground. Originally, the odor was faint, sweet and not entirely unpleasant, but later on it was reassessed as that of old ham/gym socks. The spores visualized at x400 without a mounting medium appear to be cylindric on average; their dimensions to be posted later.
A review of the NJ-PA species check list on www.amanitaceae.org guided by the morpho-traits of this collection points to A. subsolitaria.

results.notes:
A NJMA foray collection.
A single sporocarp growing in pitch pine dominated woods.
While this collection doesn’t look like any of the Suillus sp. commonly seen in the NJ Pine Barrens (americanus, brevipes, decipiens, cf. granulatus, hirtellus, salmonicolor, and spraguei), some similarity to S. decipiens can be inferred from the photos. Note the cottony ring zone near the apex. At this level of maturity, the pore surface is too dark for any of the listed taxa, but the mushroom had an appearance of being waterlogged.
This mushroom didn’t drop spores.
This collection was saved.

DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion:
An nrITS sequence fragment consisting of the first 117 bps of the locus (ITS1 region) has been obtained by Dr. Kudzma from this collection:
TCGAAATCACGATCCGGCGAGAGGAACGGAGCACGGTTGTCGCTGGTCCATCAAGGACATGTGCACGCTTTCTTCTCTACTCTCGCCGTATGGGCGCGGGGGAGGCCCGTCCCCCCC
The forward read becomes unintelligible after that (broad and distorted peaks) and the reverse read is total junk from the start. Looks like there’s been a technical difficulty with the sequencing. However, this short fragment is enough to unequivocally identify this collection as S. decipiens, as it’s a 99.2-100% match to the following GenBank accessions: AF166508, AF166509, AF1655510, KU721495, and L54079.

results.notes: The mushrooms are plentiful in an area in the woods near where I live. Their cap color ranges from a light lavender to a deeper purple / blue color on others nearby. They have purple gills and a purple stem, which is a deep purple at the top closest to the gills and cap, and about halfway down, begins to fade to a pure white, until it reaches the ground. The mushrooms grow singularly, but seem to have related specimens nearby, within a few yards of one another. They do not appear to grow very tall, measuring up to my vaporizer to give an approximate height of 3.5 inches tall. (I put a tape measurer up to my device once I returned home.) They also had a very wet, slimy texture to their caps. I appreciate anyone’s help identifying these strange mushrooms.

results.notes:
Found about 9 miles as the crow flies from Observation 334008, also under Norway Spruce.

These specimens have significantly more reticulation than that group, and were a little bit buggier. Maybe subcaerulescens instead of chippewaensis? Other than that they are very hard to distinguish. Both specimens have stuffed pores when young and yellow pores when older, with characteristic crisp/crunchy/styrofoamy texture. The smell and taste are sweet, mild and mushroomy with a notable heft.

Neither collection had any notable reaction to ammonia, KOH, or FeSO4 on either the cap or the context. Both will be submitted for DNA testing.

results.notes:
Original notes (updated 29-May-20):
> A NJMA foray collection. A single fairly mature specimen collected by an unknown foray participant.
> The morphology can be inferred from the attached images. Some brown staining of the cut flesh in the bulb. This likely the same the same species as obs 334331 featuring a button and and an immature specimens.
> Sporocarp dimensions may have been taken, but the notes have been either misplaced or lost. However, since the cap ‘footprint’ is known from a full spore print (6 cm), other notable dimensions can be extrapolated from the cross-sectional photos (to be posted later). There was no detectable odor. I did not taste this mushroom.
The mushroom dropped spores, which, when visualized at x400 without a mounting medium, looked upper-range ellipsoid to elongate. Exact measurements in Melzer’s at x1000 are TBD.
DNA sequencing results and discussion (posted on 29-May-20)
Results:
> Since this amanita was incorrectly identified (based on the misleading gross morphology) as a member of sect. Lepidella, it was sampled for nrLSU rather than nrITS. The latter locus is often found to be heterogeneous (consisting of more than one copy that cannot be resolved by conventional Sanger sequencing methodology) in members of this section, resulting in failures to obtain readable sequences.
> A clean and contiguous nrLSU sequence of 857 bps was derived from this collection by Dr. Kudzma. The sequence covers the area between the LSU0F primer (seen but edited out) and the LR5 primer, but not reaching the latter by ca. 120 bases. There are no ambiguous positions; it’s a single haplotype.
> A BLASTn-100 of this sequence revealed that this species actually belongs in sect. Amanita! The top hits are Amanita cruzii (2 accessions by T.J. Baroni, 98.8-99.2% similar)1 and Amanita roseitincta (6 accessions, mostly by R.E. Tulloss, 98.4-99.1% similar)2 from Amanita strips Roseitincta, suggesting that they are closely related.3 The sequence similarity then drastically drops to 95.3% for the next species/accession, A. fibrillopes (a rare and distinct taxon from Western Australia).4
> A phylogram consisting of carefully selected BLASTn hits was built in GenBank and uploaded to this post (Fig. 1). Therein, MO334336, A. cruzii (known from Colombia and the Dominican Republic)5 and A. roseitincta (known from eastern USA — NJ south to the Gulf Coast region)6 are shown to form a subclade at the base of sect. Amanita tree. The Asian taxa A. rufoferruginea and A. siamensis form a sister subclade. Together these 4 published taxa are assigned to subsect. Amanitella.7 The inferred phylogenetic position of these entities vis-à-vis the bulk of sect. Amanita is strongly supported by the recent multi-locus phylogenetic study of Amanitaceae by Cui et al. (2018).8 In other words, these extant taxa are presumed at this time to have originated from the earliest diverging predecessor in sect. Amanita.
Alignment of LSU sequences of MO334336, cruzii and roseitincta are shown in Fig. 2a and Fig. 2b. The overlay shows that MO334336 is different from the other two taxa in only three areas (highlighted in bright green). This comparison demonstrates that nrLSU lacks the kind of resolution one would expect of a ‘competent’ barcoding locus to discern between closely related taxa. The unusual point mutation in the highly conserved LROR primer region (a red “A” in the area highlighted in yellow) is a common trait in these three species.
Discussion:
> Based on gross morphology and DNA sequencing, the taxon represented by MO334336, as well as MO334331 that originated from the same location/foray, appears to be new to science. Ergo, the name Amanita senex Safonov, Kudzma & Tullos nom. prov. has been proposed for it. The epithet, a noun in apposition, was Rod Tulloss’ idea. It stands for ‘old man’ in Latin and refers to the all-white complexion of the fruitbodies, as well as the inferred age of the lineage to which this species belongs, as discussed above.
> To the unsuspecting eye, a cursory examination of Amanita senex may give a strong impression of a taxon in sect. Lepidella sensu Bas. Indeed, the dominant white color, superior annulus and the structure of volva on the cap consisting of prominent fibrillose pyramidal warts fit the gestalt of lepidellas. However, short marginal striations becoming visible after the volval layer is lost in age and the smooth, the non-appendiculated cap margin and the ovoid to round, non-rooting bulb all point away from sect. Lepidella s.l.
Amanita senex can be easily distinguished from A. roseitincta by its lack of the rusty-pinkish pulverulent volval underlayer present in the cap of the latter. While A. roseitincta “appears to have a duplex volva“,6 the volval structure of A. senex looks to be different (see photos).
Additional collections of A. senex, possibly include obs 141698 (in RET herbarium), obs 246833 (in RET herbarium) and obs 286409. All these known exemplars came from the outer Atlantic coastal plains of NJ and are currently presumed to be restricted to this ecological niche. The limits of distribution are unknown due to lack of suspect collections, but A. senex could perhaps be found in similar habitats both to the north and south of the NJ Pine Barrens.
References:
1 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nucleotide/KC855222.2 and https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nucleotide/KC855223.2
2 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nucleotide/MT013998.1, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nucleotide/KC855225.2, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nucleotide/KC855224.2, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nucleotide/KC855226.2, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nucleotide/MH620234.1 and https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nucleotide/AF097369.1

results.notes:
A NJMA foray collection.
One of a kind sect. Validae from the pine-oak barrens of the Atlantic coastal plains. A number such collections have been documented by me on MO (https://mushroomobserver.org/observer/observation_search?pattern=amanita+umbilicata). So far, this infrequently encountered species was known only from a very narrow geographical area (couple of sites in Franklin Parker Preserve), but it’s obviously expected to be more widespread within the confines of this particular habitat.
Brown “sun-burst” caps, remnants of a pale yellow friable volva on the lower stipe/bulb and the faint minty-floral odor (also present in at least two other species in sect. Validae, morrisii and submaculata) are the key features of this taxon.
Taller fruitbody:
> Overall height = 11.5 cm
> Cap: 5.3-5.7 cm wide; flesh is 4 mm thick above stipe
> Gills: 5.5 mm thick; short gills are rounded sub-truncate to sub-attenuate, plentiful and of diverse lengths
> Stipe: 10.5 cm long, 9 mm wide at apex, narrowing to 7 mm at ~1 cm below apex, and gradually widening to 1.2 cm just above the bulb, seemingly exannulate (PV lost); the bulb is indistinct, almost making the stipe look totally elongating, 1.4 cm wide max; stipe cortex features a shallow central canal
Shorter fruitbody:
> Overall height = ~8 cm
> Cap: 6.1-6.5 cm wide; flesh is 5 mm thick above stipe
> Gills: 7 mm wide; short gills are rounded sub-truncate to sub-attenuate, plentiful and of diverse lengths
> Stipe: 7.5 cm long, 1.2 cm wide at apex and uniformly 1-1.1 cm wide between apex and bulb, with partial veil remnant attached 2 cm below apex; bulb is 1.7 cm long and 1.5 cm wide max; stipe cortex features a shallow central canal
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted on 15-Jul-22):
> A full-length nrITS consensus sequence of two reads was obtained by Dr. Kudzma from this material and submitted by me to GenBank. There is a single ambiguity, “R” = A/G, that happens to be the last character of the 5.8S sublocus of the spacer. Fig. 1 shows the phylogenetic position of A. umbilicata in a partial ITS distance tree of section Validae. It’s a member of the “flavoconia group” and is closely related to the North American A. morrisii, which which it shares the niche habitat, and the Asian A. detersa. A photograph of the latter species in Cui et al. (2018) shows it to be a lookalike of A. imbilicata.1
Reference:
1 Cui et al., The family Amanitaceae: molecular phylogeny, higher-rank taxonomy and the species in China; Fungal Diversity 91: 5–230 (2018)

results.notes:
(a.k.a., Rough-Stemmed Stemmed, Scaber Stalked, or Birch Bolete)

MO#: 334437 iNat #: 16834401

NEARBY FLORA: Paper Birch Trees.
SUBSTRATE: Grass interspersed w/Moss on top of soil.
HABIT: Dozens loosely concentrated directly underneath the Birch Trees.
LIGHT EXPOSURE: Partial Shade to Full Sun
ODOR: Muddy, turning putrid with age.
TASTE: Non-descript.

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

CAP: Convex at first, becoming almost-flat, and when mature are Hemispheric. The surface is smooth, with fine, irregular, very-pale brown cracks becoming larger when about middle aged…this cracking disappears on mature specimens. Cap color is initially light-brown, becoming brown to reddish-brown with age; ~ 1” to 6” wide. Flesh is white, thick, firm, and is not changed where cut or bruised. Slimy when wet. Margin is distinct, regular, with sharp edges, in-rolled slightly at first. Younger to middle-aged

PORES: Free, initially light-grey, becoming olive-grey with age. Tubes are ~ ¼ “ – ¾ “ long, with1-2 pores/mm at maturity. No change when cut or bruised. Light-to-medium brown where cut or bruised.

STIPE: White, clavate, central attachment. Over the entire surface are scales/ with white to black flakes/scales, running vertically from the base to the cap underside. scaly w/very fine and closely spaced vertically running ridges, ~1.5” long. Light-to-medium brown where cut or bruised.

SPORES: e.g., White

MYCELIA: e.g., White, very dense, directly below the forest duff. Appears to run shallow in the packed substrate, ~ ½”

results.notes:
Under hemlock, hickory, sweet birch, and oak.
Fruit bodies 1-3” tall, glossy, dry, hollow and brittle. No hairs, no real bumps on stipe.
Spores are aseptate, hyaline, variable size, mostly straight but some curved
(32.2) 32.3 – 44.4 (46) × (4.6) 5 – 6.25 (6.3) µm Q = (5.1) 5.7 – 7.4 (9.6) ; N = 9 Me = 37 × 5.5 µm ; Qe = 6.5
Asci are amyloid, bitunicate, inoperculate (but not sure, its hard to tell)
(110.7) 115.5 – 139.4 (149.3) × (8.9) 11 – 12.2 (12.7) µm
Q = (10) 10.5 – 12.1 (16.7) ; N = 7 Me = 129.5 × 11.2 µm ; Qe = 11.7
Paraphyses about the same length as asci, with a slightly swollen tip, curved at the end, aseptate.

results.notes: On rotting wood in mixed deciduous forest. Growing in a cluster. Caps 0.5-1.7 cm, convex to flat, slightly depressed at disk. A little wrinkly at maturity. Bright yellow, dry and powdery. Flesh bright yellow. Gills distant, adnate to adnex, with many crossveins. White, yellowish near cap edge. Stipe 1.8-0.8 cm long x 2-3 mm thick, bright yellow, flattened, fuzzy, some fused at base.

results.notes: The infected mushroom was growing on rotting wood in a mixed forest with lots of oak and pine. The underside of the caps had drops of liquid, each with an insect in them.

results.notes: Growing in mixed hemlock birch, red maple, oak grove at edge of marsh, popping out of rotting wood. Cap 3-7.5 cm, gray brown, sometimes darker in the center, dry (not velvety) and somewhat wrinkly, especially with age. Flat to depressed at center, edges becoming scalloped. Gills creamy white, decurrent to subdecurrent, distant to subdistant, smooth edges. Latex white, unchanging. Stipe 3.5-4 cm long x 8-10 mm thick, concolorous with cap, hollow with edge, flesh cream.

results.notes: This mushroom was very long and looked like the cap hadn’t opened properly. It had a brown tint with some hints of pink/red on the cap. The pores were white and bruised brown. It was growing on the ground in a mixed forest with lots of oak and pine.

Findlay, Hancock Co., Ohio, USA

results.notes: Growing from soil in mixed pine, birch, oak woods. Cap tan with pinkish and purplish tones, smooth and dry. 7-11 cm, taste very bitter. Pores cream to pinkish tan, do not bruise when young, bruising slightly darker pink when older. Tubes 1 cm long. Stipe colored as cap except cream colored at the apex and sometimes browner at the base, 2-3 cm thick x 3-5 cm long, some with very fine reticulation at the apex. Chemical reactions: cap surface negative with Fe, pale yellow with ammonia, pale orange with KOH; flesh light blue with Fe, negative with ammonia and KOH.
results.location_name: Pelham, Hampshire Co., Massachusetts, USA

results.notes: Growing on a mossy hummock and in a birch/hemlock stand in a marshy area. Cap 15-30 mm, conical and sometimes slightly umbonate, pinkish orange. Gills attached, colored as cap, subdistant. Stipe 3-6 mm thick x 7-8 cm long, colored as cap or slightly paler, often flattened and sometimes twisted, creamy orange mycelia at the base.
results.location_name: Pelham, Hampshire Co., Massachusetts, USA

results.notes: Inside rotting hemlock stump in mixed forest. Caps 1.5-4 cm, yellow with reddish brown scales all over. Stipe 3-5 cm x 5-7 mm thick, equal, smooth and yellow. Gills close, yellow. Spores ellipsoid, 4.8-5.9 × 3.2-3.8, Pleurocystidia absent, cheilocystidia of various shapes, thin-walled and inflated. Clamp connections present.
results.location_name: Pelham, Hampshire Co., Massachusetts, USA

results.notes: Under white pine. Flesh is white bruising to tan pretty quickly then darker. Cap brown to orange. Stem looks spotted.
results.location_name: Altamont, New York, USA

results.notes: From ground in mixed birch, oak, red maple, hemlock forest. Caps 2-4 cm, dark golden yellow, viscid, somewhat wrinkled. Cap flesh white to pale yellow. Pores pale yellow, unbruising. Stipe 6-8 mm thick at apex, swollen to 1-1.5 cm and often curved toward the base. Pale yellow and covered with reddish punctae except at the apex. Stipe flesh whitish to very pale yellow, slowly staining dull pink overall with bright blue specks in the base. Ammonia and KOH red on cap surface.

results.notes: From the same population as MO#292785. In wet boggy area dominated by Sphagnum moss. Growing on living and dead moss, small dead twigs and dead leaves mixed in among the moss. Caps 2-10 mm, white, gills well developed, distant. Little to no stipe, stipe eccentric when present, fuzzy at point of attachment. Many branched hyphae and clamp connections in hyphae of cap. Monomitic with simple-septate generative hyphae. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores brown and longitudinally ridged. Spore measurements from Piximetre: (14.5) 15.4 – 20.2 (21.4) × (7.7) 8.3 – 10.3 (11.5) µm, Q = (1.6) 1.7 – 2.2 (2.5); N = 30, Me = 17.6 × 9.3 µm; Qe = 1.9

notes_fields.Substrate/Host: At the base of an undetermined, small, rotting stump in the vicinity of sycamore trees
notes_fields.Habitat: partly flooded mixed hardwood-conifer forest (western hemlock, pine, birch, maple, oak, hickory, sycamore, rhododendron)
notes_fields.Comments:
Spores:
(14.3) 15.2 – 17.8 (19) × (4) 4.4 – 4.7 (5.3) µm
Q = (3.3) 3.4 – 3.9 (4) ; N = 10
Me = 16.7 × 4.6 µm ; Qe = 3.6

This material, while not in great shape, was collected for the striking presence of blue pigment at the base of two of the fruiting bodies. The only species known to me with this quality is M. cyanobasis, described from northern Spain, and whatever species is shown in this observation from Colombia:

https://mushroomobserver.org/199675

for which there is neither microscopy or a vouchered specimen. The curved apices of the paraphyses are said to be diagnostic of that species. At best, the paraphyses here were forked, but not curved.
